text: this truffle used to be used for tea
ceremonies and one day they just decided
to grill some meat what we have in front
of us is true binchotan charcoal right
it comes from oak wood it's a super
condensed compressed charcoal from
Wakayama Prefecture in Japan this char
has been made for about 1,200 years it
dates back to the Edo period
it burns four times longer than American
charcoal it definitely becomes a ritual
it's considerably expensive you have to
light the charcoal the right way and
then you have to fill your box it's
important to vessel that you use it's
not your typical grilling when you
typically grill on American charcoal and
the fat drips it hits the charcoal and
it catches on fire this doesn't
necessarily do that when the juice hits
the charcoal it creates a little cloud
and then the cloud comes up and it
engulfs the meat and that's what
actually gives the meat the flavor of
grill there's also restaurants that use
the charcoal and directly touch proteins
they would make sushi and to impart a
nice little smoky flavor but still keep
the fish raw they would grab the
charcoal just touch the fish with it
binchotan also acts as a water purifier
put it right in here and they'll sink
down to the bottom and it'll just start
filtering in the water there's actually
some restaurants in New York City that
used it to filter the water I've seen it
at Forge Marc Forgione's restaurant they
actually serve a bottle of water with
the charcoal in it it's also used in
cosmetic they use it for facials soaps
internally they take it to clean your
system to fight bacteria purifies the
air as well it's supposed to take away
odors there's a lot of purposes for it
but we use it for grilling at our
restaurant
you know if we're gonna grill why not
grill on the best product that we can
get that's been made for so many years
in a very specific way and it's been
perfected and it just results in a
beautiful product when you serve your
guests at the restaurant
